articles.title: Cities face 'whiplash' of floods, droughts as temperatures rise, study warns
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: Rising temperatures play havoc with the global water cycle. South and Southeast Asia face the strongest wetting trends, while Europe, the Middle East and North Africa are becoming drier. Hangzhou and Jakarta are suffering from 'climate whiplash', or a rapid succession of prolonged floods and droughts. Dallas, Shanghai and Baghdad are also suffering from extreme flood and drought risks.

articles.title: Extreme ocean heat does not mean climate change is accelerating: study
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: There was a huge jump in global sea surface temperatures between March 2023 and April 2024. It was 0.25 degrees Celsius above the previous record. Such an event occurs every 500 years with the current warming trend. Without climate change, it would have been impossible without human-driven climate change.

articles.title: Loiyangalani residents lose houses and cattle after heavy downpour
articles.author: STAR REPORTER
articles.summary: The annual rainfall in Marsabit has caused a disaster for the residents of Loiyangalani. The few cattle they managed to salvage were swept away by flash floods. 20 households lost their income, houses, and cattle in the floods. The Kenya Meteorological Department has predicted more rain in the coming days.

articles.title: Lewis Hamilton ready to race for Ferrari for the first time in F1's season-opening Australian GP
articles.author: Heath McKinley
articles.summary: Lewis Hamilton is racing for Ferrari for the first time. Reigning world champion Max Verstappen is arriving without a lot of mileage in his Red Bull. Lando Norris is helping McLaren set a benchmark with his pace in testing. Formula 1 is expecting a hyper-competitive milestone with the 75th anniversary season in 2025. It starts this weekend with the Australian Grand Prix.

articles.title: Sea levels rise by 'unexpected' amount in 2024: NASA
articles.author: Paul ELLIS
articles.summary: Global sea levels rose more than expected in 2024, Earth's hottest year on record, according to NASA. Last year's increase was due to an unusual amount of ocean warming and meltwater from land-based ice such as glaciers, NASA says.

articles.title: Ex-NOAA chief: Trump firings put lives, jobs, and science in jeopardy
articles.author: Chandan KHANNA
articles.summary: Rick Spinrad was director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration under the Biden administration. He spoke to AFP about the agency's role in public safety, scientific research and protecting the American economy in the Trump administration's plans for the next wave of federal layoffs.

articles.author: Paul ELLIS
articles.summary: Global sea levels rose more than expected in 2024, Earth's hottest year on record, according to an analysis released by the US space agency NASA. Last year's increase was due to an unusual amount of ocean warming and meltwater from land-based ice such as glaciers.

articles.title: Spain to face increasingly 'severe' droughts: report
articles.author: THOMAS COEX
articles.summary: Dry spells in Spain will become more frequent and severe due to global warming, according to the Clivar network that studies climate change. Spain has long faced "semi-permanent water stress" due to its geographic location. The Mediterranean country is near the end of a drought.

articles.title: Lewis Hamilton ready to race for Ferrari for the first time in F1's season-opening Australian GP
articles.author: Heath McKinley
articles.summary: Lewis Hamilton, Max Verstappen and Lando Norris will race at the Australian Grand Prix this weekend. It's the 75th anniversary season of Formula 1 and it starts this weekend with the Melbourne Grand Prix. There's no shortage of unknowns in terms of pecking order and weather.
